Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: Improved Limits from DRIFT and R&D Towards Improved Directionality and Sensitivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this era of precision cosmology, measurements suggest that ordinary matter represents only a fraction of the total matter density in the Universe. The rest, whose effect we can see only gravitationally, is unknown in its nature and is termed Dark Matter. Particle physics models suggest that dark matter is composed of relic Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, left over from the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays. Experimental efforts to detect WIMPs are extremely challenging due to the predicted small interaction probabilities and the existence of backgrounds that mimic the expected signal. Fortunately, a number of unique dark matter signatures exist that can be used to discriminate against backgrounds and decisively identify WIMP interactions. The largest and most robust signature is the predicted dependence of the WIMP flux on the Sun-Earth velocity through the Galaxy, yielding a sidereal modulation of the nuclear recoil direction in the laboratory.

The Directional Recoil Identification From Tracks (DRIFT) dark matter experiment is a leader in the field of directional dark matter detection, with sensitivity to the powerful angular signature of nuclear recoils induced by WIMPs. The intellectual merit of this award resides in DRIFT's powerful capabilities being brought to bear on one of the most important questions in science today. The collaboration will be testing their next prototype detector, DRIFT-IIe, above ground at Occidental College. It features an inherently scalable design including a redesigned field cage, a texturized, thin-film cathode, a new, transparent wire readout which doubles the fiducial volume per readout, and a new every-wire data acquisition system which allows for lower noise and fiducialization in the detector plane.

The potential of DRIFT's capabilities have promising applications to Homeland Security and double-beta decay experiments. Broader impacts of this work also include the training of a diverse set of undergraduate and graduate students (including underrepresented minorities) in increasingly rare small-scale experiments, giving them exposure to a wide range of research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this era of precision cosmology, measurements suggest that ordinary matter represents only a fraction of the total matter density in the Universe. The rest, whose presence we only infer gravitationally, is unknown in its nature, and is called "dark matter". A leading hypothesis is that dark matter consists of relic Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) left over from the Big Bang. Experimental efforts to directly detect WIMPs are extremely challenging due to small interaction probabilities and large backgrounds that mimic the expected signal. 

Fortunately, a robust dark matter signature exists to discriminate against backgrounds and definitively identify WIMP interactions. The motion of the Earth through the galaxy produces a head-wind of WIMPs. The angular distribution of recoils from WIMP interactions has a ~100% asymmetry, and is modulated at the sidereal rate on account of the Earth's rotation. No known background can mimic this signal. The intellectual merit of this proposal resides in the Directional Recoil Identification From Tracks (DRIFT) dark matter experiment's sensitivity to this signature, which provides a unique window into one of the most important questions in science today. 

This grant was one of several funded by the NSF on the DRIFT directional dark matter experiment. The cumulative effort on this joint US-UK experiment has led to enormous experimental progress on a number of fronts. The most significant pertained to background reduction. When DRIFT first took underground data over a decade ago in the UK Boulby Mine, a large background indistinguishable from dark matter signals was discovered. It was soon revealed that this was due to radon progeny, which led to a large effort on reducing radon emanation and developing methods to improve the vetoing power of the detector and, ultimately, to fully fiducialize the detector. This R&D resulted in a number of technological advances, including an ultra-thin film cathode that provided a veto efficiency for alpha decays at >99% from its surface, and a discovery by our Occidental collaborators that led to full fiducialization of the detector. With a new detector that incorporated these advances, the experiment took dark matter data for over 100 days with zero backgrounds. This data was used to publish two limits on spin-dependent cross-sections from dark matter-proton interactions.

Progress was also made on a number of R&D projects related to improving the sensitivity of directional dark matter searches. One led to the discovery of a new negative-ion gas mixture, SF6+CF4, which includes a number of advantages over the DRIFT gas while maintaining its benefits (low diffusion and fiducialization). Another project used micro-patterned gas detectors (MPGDs) coupled to CCD-based optical readouts, which provided high granularity and signal-to-noise to image low energy recoil tracks. Data taken with a detector based on this technology achieved the lowest discrimination threshold in 100 Torr CF4 to date. Other R&D, also based on MPGDs, demonstrated a novel TPC readout that could provide a low-cost, robust path towards scale-up of future directional dark matter detectors.

The work in this proposal has broader impacts beyond direct dark matter searches. The use of negative-ion gases could benefit other rare search applications like neutrino-less double-beta, KK axions and beam-dump dark matter searches. Our work on imaging and reconstructing very low energy electron and nuclear recoil tracks could also have applications in X-ray polarimetry. This work has also included the training of a diverse set of undergraduates and graduate students in increasingly rare small-scale experiments, giving them exposure to a wide range of research experience.
